question: Passing twelve hundred feet...
answer: Blowing main tanks!

question: Twelve hundred fifty feet...
answer: Main forward tanks ruptured!

question: Passing thirteen hundred feet...
answer: Too deep to pump auxiliaries!

question: Fred, huh? I don't know. Hurricanes should be named after women.
answer: I can't believe you let them do this!

question: Hi, Lins. I thought you were in Houston.
answer: I was, but I managed to bum a ride on the last flight out here. Only here isn't where I left it, is it, Bud?

question: Wasn't up to me.
answer: We were that close to proving a submersible drilling platform could work. We had over seven thousand feet of hole down for Chrissake. I can't believe you let them grab my rig!

question: Your rig?
answer: My rig. I designed the damn thing.

question: Yup, a Benthic Petroleum paid for it. So as long as they're hold the pink slip, I go where they tell me.
answer: You wimp. I had a lot riding on this. They bought you... more like least rented you cheap--

question: I'm switching off now.
answer: Virgil, you wiener! You never could stand up to fight. You--

question: Those guys are about a much fun as a tax audit. Hippy, you're going to give that rat a disease.
answer: Well, well. Mrs. Brigman.

question: Not for long.
answer: You never did like being called that, did you?

question: Not even when it meant something. Is that One Night up in Flatbed?
answer: Who else?

question: I can't believe you were dumb enough to come down. Now you're stuck here for the storm... dumb, hot-rod... dumb.
answer: Look, I didn't come down here to fight.

question: Then why'd you come down?
answer: You need me. Nobody knows the systems on this rig better than I do. What is something was to go wrong after the Explorer clears off? What would have you done?

question: Wow, you're right! Us poor dumb ol' boys might've had to think for ourselves. Coulda been a disaster. You wanna know what I think?
answer: Not particularly. Jeez, look where this is set! Morons.

question: I think you were worried about me.
answer: That must be it.

question: No, I think you were. Come on, admit it.
answer: I was worried about the rig. I've got over four years invested in this project.

question: Oh, yeah, right... and you only had three years with me.
answer: You've got to have priorities.

question: My bunk's the only one I can guarantee won't be occupied. You can grab a couple hours before we get there.
answer: What are you still wearing that for?

question: I don't know. Divorce ain't final. Forgot to take it off.
answer: I haven't worn mine in months.

question: Yeah, what's-his-name wouldn't like it. The Suit.
answer: Do you always have to call him that? The Suit? It makes you sound like such a hick. His name is Michael.

question: So what about "Michael" then... Mr. Brooks Brothers... Mr. BMW. You still seeing him?
answer: No, I haven't seen him in a few weeks.

question: What happened?
answer: Bud, why are you doing this? It's not part of you life any more.

question: I'll tell you what happened... you woke up one day and realized the guy never made you laugh.
answer: You're right, Bud. It was just that simple. Aren't you clever? You should get your own show... Ask Dr. Bud, advice to the lovelorn from three hundred fathoms. AAAARRRGGH! Shit.

question: On the dive, you will do absolutely nothing without direct orders from me, and you will follow my instructions without discussion. Is this clear? Alright, I want everyone finished prep and ready to get wet in fifteen minutes.
answer: Look, it's three AM. These guys are running on bad coffee and four hours sleep. You better start cutting them some slack.

question: I can't afford slack, Brigman.
answer: Hey, you come on my rig, you don't talk to me, you start ordering my guys around. It won't work. You gotta know how to handle these people... we have a certain way of doing things here.

question: Knock off the chatter. Cab One, you getting anything? Cab One, do you see it yet?
answer: The magnetometer is pegged. Side-scan is showing a big return, but I don't see anything yet. Are you sure you got the depth right on this? Uh, yeah, roger that... uh, found it.

question: Cab One, radiation readings?
answer: Neutron counter's not showing very much.

question: Wilhite, anything? Just continue forward along the hull.
answer: Copy that, continuing forward. You just want me to get shots of everything, right?

question: Roger, document as much as you can, but keep moving. We're on a tight timeline.
answer: Copy that.

question: Radiation is nominal. The warheads must still be intact.
answer: How many are there?

question: 24 Trident missiles. Eight MIRVs per missile.
answer: That's 192 warheads... And how powerful are they? Jesus Christ... this is World War Three in a can.

question: Okay, Cat, Lew, Sonny. You guys stay on this deck. Hook you line onto mine. Any problem, you tug my line. Two pulls. Jammer, you're with me.
answer: Where are we?

question: Missile compartment. Those are the launch tubes.
answer: Lord Almighty.

question: Hey, you okay? Deep and slow, big guy. Deep and slow. Just breathe easy.
answer: I... they're all dead, Bud. They're all dead. I thought... some of them... you know...

question: I'm taking you back out.
answer: No! I'm okay now. I just don't... I can't go any further in.

question: Okay, Jammer. No problem. You stay right here. I have to go there to the end... you'll see my lights. We'll stay in voice contact. Just hold onto the rope. Five more minutes. Okay?
answer: Yeah, okay. Okay. Bud? BUD?! You readin' me? BUD?!! Bud? Is that you?

question: Did you get anything on the cameras. Video or anything?
answer: No. Look, forget it. I don't want to talk about it.

question: Fine. Be that way.
answer: I don't know what I saw. Okay? Coffey wants to call it a Russian submersible, fine. It's a Russian submersible. No problem.

question: But you think it's something else. What? One of ours?
answer: No.

question: Whose then? Lindsey? Talk to me...
answer: Jammer saw something in there, something that scared the hell out him--

question: His mixture got screwed up. He panicked and pranged his regulator.
answer: But what did he see that made him panic?

question: What do you think he saw?
answer: I don't know. I DON'T KNOW!

question: What's the scoop, ace?
answer: I can get power to this module and sub-bay if I remote these busses. I've gotta get past the mains, which are a total melt-down.

question: Need some help?
answer: Thanks. No, I can handle it. Bud... there won't be enough to run the heaters. In a couple hours this place is going to be as cold as a meat locker.

question: What about O-2?
answer: Brace yourself. We've got about 12 hours worth if we close off the sections we're not using.

question: The storm's gonna last longer than 12 hours.
answer: I can extend that. There's some storage tanks outboard on the wrecked module. I'll have to go outside to tie onto them.

question: Hey, Lins... I'm glad your here.
answer: Yeah? Well I'm not.

question: Where're you?
answer: Quarters. Level two. That's Perry.

question: That's it then. Finler, McWhirter, Dietz, and Perry. Jesus.
answer: Do we just leave him there?

question: Gimme a three-eighths socket on a long extension. So there you were--
answer: There we were, side by side, on the same ship, for two months. I'm tool-pusher and we're testing this automated derrick of hers. So, we get back on the beach and... we're living together.

question: Doesn't mean you had to marry her.
answer: We were due to go back out on the same ship. Six months of tests. If you were married you got a state-room. Otherwise it was bunks.

question: Okay, good reason. Then what?
answer: It was alright for a while, you know. But then she got promoted to project engineer on this thing, couple years ago.

question: She went front-office on you. Tighten that for me, right there. That's it.
answer: Well, you know Lindsey, too damn aggressive-- Son of a--!! She didn't leave me... she just left me behind.

question: Hippy, do me a favor... stay off my side.
answer: Lindsey, will you step into my office for a minute... Jesus, Lindsey--

question: Bud, something really important is happening here.
answer: Look. I'm just trying to hold this situation together. I can't allow you to cause this kind of hysteria--

question: Who's hysterical? Nobody's hysterical!
answer: All I'm saying is when you're hanging on by your fingernails, you don't go waving you arms around.

question: I saw something! I'm not going to go back there and say I didn't see it when I did. I'm sorry.
answer: God, you are the most stubborn woman I ever knew.

question: I need you to believe me, Bud. Look at me. Do I seem stressed out? Any of the symptoms of pressure sickness, any tremors, slurred speech?
answer: No.

question: Bud, this is me, Lindsey. Okay? You know me better than anybody in the world. Now watch my lips... I saw these things. I touched one of them. And it wasn't some clunky steel can like we would build... it glided. It was the most beautiful thing I've ever seen. It was a machine, but it seems almost alive. Like a... dance of light. Bud, you have to trust me... please. I don't think they mean us harm. I don't know how I know that, it's just a feeling.
answer: How can I go on a feeling? You think Coffey's going to go on you 'feeling'?

question: We all see what we want to see... Coffey looks and he sees Russians, he sees hate and fear. Bud, you have to look with better eyes than that.
answer: I can't, Lindsey. I'm sorry. How can I?

question: You've got some huevos bringing this... thing... into my rig! With everything that's been going on up in the world, you bring a nuclear weapon in here? Does this strike anyone as particularly psychotic, or is it just me?
answer: You don't need to know the details of this mission... you're better off if you don't.

question: You're right... I don't. I just need to know that this thing is out of here! You hear me, Roger Ramjet?
answer: Mrs. Brigman, you're becoming a serious impediment to this mission. I believe the stress is affecting you. Escort her to quarters and have Monk prepare a tranquilizer.

question: Man, I give this a sphincter-factor of about nine point five.
answer: Look, you can just punch into his little chip where you want him to go, and he goes, right?

question: Well, yeah, but the tether off it ain't gonna be fancy. When he gets down there he'll just sit, like a dumb-shit. Unless something wanders through view of the camera, you'll get nada.
answer: Let's go for it. We could get lucky.

question: I don't know. I really oughta talk to Bud about this.
answer: No. Just you and me. We get some proof, then tell them. Hippy, look... if was can prove to Coffey it's not Russians, maybe he'll ease off the button a little.

question: Uh, okay, right. You can tell us about it later. Let's go. He's jammed the mechanism.
answer: Now what?

question: Okay, I'm gonna free-swim to hatch six... get inside, get the door open from the other side.
answer: Bud, that water's only a couple degrees above freezing.

question: Then I guess you better wish me luck, huh?
answer: Wish us luck. 'Case I don't die. Okay, Bud... let's go, podner, I ain't got all day.

question: Hafta... go on to... the moonpool. Only way.
answer: I can't... make it... podner.

question: Get in! You owe me one, Virgil.
answer: Can we negotiate later? There's Big Geek. Go after it! We gotta catch it!

question: You did okay, back there. I was fairly impressed.
answer: Not good enough. We still gotta catch Big Geek.

question: Not in this thing.
answer: You totaled it, huh?

question: Yeah. So sue me.
answer: It's flooding like a son of the bitch.

question: You noticed. Deepcore, Deepcore, this is Cab One, over.
answer: Try again.

question: Deepcore, this is Cab One. We need assistance, over. Deepcore, this-- Well, that's that.
answer: Wonderful. There's some light from somewhere...

question: Over there. It's the rig.
answer: Good hundred yards, I'd say.

question: They'll come out after us.
answer: Yeah, but it's gonna take them a while to find us. We better get this flooding stopped.

question: You see where it's coming in?
answer: Somewhere behind this panel. Hold this. Can't get to it. Have to pull this panel off. You go any tools?

question: I don't know, look around.
answer: Nothing. Son of a bitch. All I need's a goddamn crescent wrench. Son of a bitch!

question: Calm down, Bud.
answer: Okay... okay. We gotta get you out of here.

question: How?
answer: I don't know how!

question: We've only got one suit.
answer: I know! I know! But we better come up with something.

question: Aaargh!! I'm freezing! Okay, look, you swim to the rig and come back with another suit.
answer: Seven, eight minute swim each way... not enough time. Look at this... Time I get back you'll be-- Alright, put this on.

question: What, you growing gills all of a sudden? You got it on, keep it on.
answer: Don't argue, goddamnit, just--

question: No way! Forget it. Not an option.
answer: Lindsey, just put the thing on and shut up--

question: NO!! Now be logical, Bud, you're--
answer: FUCK LOGIC!!

question: Listen... will you listen to me for a second!? You're for the suit on and you're a better swimmer than me. Right? So I got a plan...
answer: What's the plan?

question: I drown, you tow me back to the rig--
answer: WHAT KIND OF PLAN IS THAT!??

question: Look, this water is only a couple degrees above freezing. I drown. I go into deep hypothermia... my blood like icewater. I can maybe be revived after ten, fifteen minutes. You got all the stuff to do it on the rig.
answer: It is insane.

question: It's the only way, Bud. Now trust me.
answer: Jesus, I don't believe this is happening. Oh God, Lins... I--

question: Tell me later. This is maybe not such a great plan, is it? Hold me. Hold me, Bud... I'm so scared...
answer: NOOOOO!!!

question: No! NO! She's not... her heart is strong, she wants to live... can't you see that? Come on, Lins. Come on, baby! Zap her again! Do it... DO IT! Come on, breath! Goddamn it, you bitch, you never backed down from anything in life... now fight! Fight, Goddamnit! FIGHT!! Come on, Lins. You can do it... fight your way back, baby... You did it, ace.
answer: Hey... big boys don't cry, remember?

question: Hi, lady.
answer: Hi, tough guy. I guess it worked, huh?

question: 'Course is worked. You're never wrong, are you? How d'you feel.
answer: I've been better. Next time it's your turn, okay?

question: Well, you got that right.
answer: No, Bud, no... not you.

question: Deepcore, do you read? This is Benthic Explorer, over.
answer: Hell yes, we read! Good of you to join us. How's that storm doin'?

question: Well, it's strange... it just kind've blew itself out all of the sudden. We're up here in a flat sea with no wind. But then a lot of weird things've been happening.
answer: Well, hell, son. You better get us a line down here, we're in moderately poor shape.
